sections.title: Intro & Prerequisites
sections.summary: Presenter states the goal (deploy two models used by the demo locally) and lists required tools and dependencies.
key_actions: Outline deployment steps for demo models
List required tools: Visual Studio, Docker, PowerShell, .NET 9, Azure CLI

sections.title: Azure CLI Login / Tenant Selection
sections.summary: Log in to Azure using the tenant option to access the Cloud Advocate tenant and select the correct subscription.
key_actions: Run az login with tenant option
Ensure correct subscription / tenant is selected

sections.title: Create Resource Group with Deployment Script
sections.summary: Run a command to create a new resource group (example name given) which provisions necessary resources; process completes in about 2 minutes and outputs JSON.
key_actions: Run command to create resource group (example: RGBR CAR 447)
Wait ~2 minutes for deployment to complete
Inspect JSON output for resource information

sections.title: Retrieve Outputs: Keys and Endpoints
sections.summary: Demonstrates getting the deployment output values (keys, endpoint, foundry name) from the CLI output and copying the foundry name for later use.
key_actions: Use 'get output' or equivalent to retrieve keys from deployment JSON
Copy foundry name and endpoint from output
ui_elements: Output JSON with keys and endpoints

sections.title: Update Script with Resource/Account Names
sections.summary: Populate a small script with the retrieved resource group name and account name, then paste and prepare to run it in the console.
key_actions: Edit script to include resource group name and account name
Copy updated script into console application
Clear console and prepare to run script
ui_elements: Resource name and account name variables

sections.title: Run Script => Obtain Connection String, Endpoint, Key; Dashboard Prompt
sections.summary: Run the script to generate connection strings, endpoints, and keys. On first run the application dashboard opens and prompts for an AI Foundry parameter which must be pasted and saved to user secrets.
key_actions: Execute script to produce connection string, endpoint, and key
Open application dashboard when first run
Paste AI Foundry parameter into prompted field
Save the parameter to user secrets to avoid re-entering

sections.title: Application Running — Browse & Semantic Search
sections.summary: With the parameter saved and the app running, demonstrate browsing the product and performing a semantic search to test functionality.
key_actions: Browse application UI
Perform semantic search to verify embeddings and search features

sections.title: Editing User Secrets / Switching Resources
sections.summary: Show how to change which resource the app points to by editing the App host user secrets: remove existing AI Foundry line, rerun, and add a different line as needed.
key_actions: Open App host and edit user secrets
Delete existing AI Foundry entry
Rerun application and add a new AI Foundry value
ui_elements: AI Foundry entry in user secrets

sections.title: Check Resource Group in Azure Portal & Inspect OpenAI Deployments
sections.summary: Navigate to the created resource group in the Azure portal, open the Azure OpenAI resource to view deployments (example: GPT 41 mini for chats/text embedding and ADI O2 for embeddings) and retrieve endpoints and keys from the portal.
key_actions: Open Azure Portal -> Resource Groups -> select created group
Open Azure OpenAI resource
View deployments list and specific deployment names
Copy endpoints and keys from portal as needed
ui_elements: Deployments list (e.g., GPT 41 mini, ADI O2)

main_topics: Deploying demo models/resources via Azure CLI
Retrieving deployment outputs: endpoints and keys
Configuring local application (scripts and user secrets)
Using the application dashboard and testing semantic search
Inspecting Azure Portal resources and OpenAI deployments
